Call $x_1,x_2,\ldots \in (0,1)$ well-distributed if, for every $\epsilon>0$, if $k$ is sufficiently large then, for all $n>0$ and intervals $I\subseteq [0,1]$,\[\lvert \# \{ n<m\leq n+k : x_m\in I\} - \lvert I\rvert k\rvert < \epsilon k.\]Is it true that, for every $\alpha$, the sequence $\{ \alpha p_n\}$ is not well-distributed, if $p_n$ is the sequence of primes?



The notion of a well-distributed sequence was introduced by Hlawka and Petersen \cite{Hl55}.

Erd\H{o}s proved that, if $n_k$ is a lacunary sequence, then the sequence $\{ \alpha n_k\}$ is not well-distributed for almost all $\alpha$.

He also claimed in \cite{Er64b} to have proved that there exists an irrational $\alpha$ for which $\{\alpha p_n\}$ is not well-distributed. He later retracted this claim in \cite{Er85e}, saying "The theorem is no doubt correct and perhaps will not be difficult to prove but I never was able to reconstruct my 'proof' which perhaps never existed ."

The existence of such an $\alpha$ was established by Champagne, Le, Liu, and Wooley \cite{CLLW24}.




References


[CLLW24] J. Champagne, T. Le, Y.-R. Liu, and T. D. Wooley, Well-distribution modulo one and the primes. arXiv:2406.19491 (2024).

[Er64b] Erd\H{o}s, P., Problems and results on diophantine approximations. Compositio Math. (1964), 52-65.

[Er85e] Erd\H{o}s, P., Some problems and results in number theory. Number theory and combinatorics. Japan 1984 (Tokyo,
Okayama and Kyoto, 1984) (1985), 65-87.
